author: Dylan Pollard

review: Chromecast fills the Gap where Roku 3 is lacking.  I own a Roku 3 and love it.  However, I purchased Chromecast for one reason and one reason only.  I wanted to be able to go back and watch CBS Elementary full episodes 8-11 season 2 on my 46" HDTV for FREE.  These episodes are not available on Netflix or Hulu.  But now that I have Chromecast I can use Google Chrome and cast them over WIFI.  So for me the $30 is very well spent.Chromecast is also a good investment because it's a Google product.  I expect in 2014 to see many more apps developed on the market for this device.

review: We love the Google Chromecast and can't wait for google to augment some of its features. It has been steadily increasing the apps that work with its cast capability. When we first purchased it, only YouTube, Netflix, Hulu, and Pandora casted successfully. HBO Go and Google Play Music also work now! The Chrome browser does cast and allow for browsing, but video streaming does not quite work yet. This was our biggest disappointment and we have high hopes that Google will fix this!

review: The promise is great and some reviews rave about how easy it is to use.  I'll admit, setup was easy and it started streaming in very little time, however there are some major setbacks.  First of all I'm using this on a Core2Duo Sony Windows 7 Pro 64-bit laptop with 8GB of RAM which has no problem streaming HD video over the HDMI cabled connection which I do all the time.  The Chromecast seemed like the perfect way to avoid having a cable suspended across the living room --- wrong.  The video quality is high-definition-ish, but jumpy and jittery as well as being constantly out of sync with the audio with every video I tried.  I tried several different videos and sites (YouTube, NBC, LFDH, Netflix, etc.) to be sure it wasn't just one site that was having an issue, but it was all due to the Chromecast.  Whether it is the dongle, itself or the software, I don't know, but that's another issue.  You MUST use Google Chrome to stream to the Chromecast (hence the name, I suppose) and it can only stream from within that browser; it can't be used to stream PowerPoint presentations or anything outside the Chrome browser window which is disappointing.
